newsitem.title: USA: Salomon Informix upgrade mixed with lower EPS view.
newsitem.headline: Salomon Informix upgrade mixed with lower EPS view.

text.p: Salomon Brothers analyst Neil Herman upgraded Informix Corp Wednesday, but his reasoning sounded largely similar to that of other analysts who have issued downgrades on the stock in recent days.
While boosting his rating to buy from neutral, Herman said he lowered his earnings estimates for the company's current and upcoming years, in line with other analysts.

The main difference between the two camps of Wall Street analysts appears to be over Informix's valuation. "If you look at the stock from a valuation basis, it looks pretty attractive" at around 23 times earnings, Herman argued.
Historically, the stock has traded at 26 times earnings, he noted.

Conversely, while Alex. Brown analyst Jim Moore cut his earnings view, Wednesday, citing near-term risks, he said he was confident of the stock's long-term prospects as Informix prepares to offer its next generation database system.

Herman estimated Informix will report $0.24 per share in the fourth quarter of 1996, versus his previous $0.28 per share estimate. Accordingly, he lowered his 1996 year estimate to $0.66 per share from $0.70 per share.
In addition, he projected the company would earn $0.95 per share in 1997, down from his prior view of $1.05 for the year. "I think 1997 is going to be a good year," Herman said.
"From a long-term perspective, the stock will do well," although he cautioned that, "near-term, it's somewhat questionable," sounding a note similar to Informix doubters.
